text: Black pour tan head cherries and coffe roast in aroma. Medium mouthfeel with cherries all in. Finishes stout like with cherries in finish.
Awesome cherry aroma with some roast going on as well. Perfect stout characteristics with awesome cherry flavors. A perfect balance of the two!

Bottle thanks to Homer! Pours cloudy reddish mahogany, small beige head, dissipates quickly, some lacing. Aroma is SOOOOOO cherry, maybe a bit of chocolate as well. Flavor is fully sweet, tons of cherries, a touch of chocolate. Medium body, low carbonation, creamy, some acidity.

Thanks to a BIF box of years past. Pours cola black with a think fizzy white top that quickly disappears. Aroma is sweet cherry, a little tart but mostly sweetness. Taste is again very tart like a cherry juice but backed with the complexity of a stout, the roasted malts and oak dryness just add amazingness to this beer. Want more.

"more tart cherries than the Bells version, which i also like. just depends what youre in the mood for i guess. not a lot of stout qualities come through in this thinnish dark brown ale. just a touch of chocolate and roasted malt after the tasty intense cherry flavors. i like it about the same as Bells, but its a totally different brew. this is a very nice cherry beer w/a side of stout, while Bells is a stout w/a side of cherries"

Bottle as Unplugged from Bu11zeye. Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma is extreme cherry. Tad sour. Med body. Flavor is very red cherry with sugar and tartness. Touch of oak . Finishes very, very cherry. Nice stuff
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours dark brown with a tiny beige head and a strong cherry aroma. There is a mellow cherry flavor, the Great Lakes version of Schaarbeekse, with a hint of oak. Very nice.
Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours cola with white head. Big cherry aroma. Taste is great roasted malts with sour cherrys. Mellow clean taste amazing stuff.

Heavy cherry smell. Tastes like Belgian Red mixed with a bit of nice stout that gives it a bit of a chocolate covered cherry taste. This beer is absolutely delicious in every way. Its a shame that this is a Thumbprint rather than an annual release since I would absolutely love to have as much of this as possible.

On tap at Brat Stop, Kenosha, WI. Pours a clear dark red with small pink head. Aroma is predominantly dark cherries, with a touch of sweet chocolate. This tastes more like cherry soda than a beer, but is interesting nonetheless. Body is medium with average carbonation and a soft palate.

Aroma: big burst of cherries, a touch on the medicinal (cherry cough syrup) side, dark malts, cocoa. 
Appearance: dark brown / ruby color, good clarity, big khaki head dissipates to a ring fairly quickly.
Taste: lots of cherries, lightly acidic, low bitterness, light hints of cocoa and dark malts. Not much in the way of stout character, but a nice fruit beer.
Palate: medium body and carbonation.
Overall: a nice fruit beer, pleasant acidity.

Dark brown with reddish tint... Aroma is cherry candy, chocolate covered... Flavor is chocolate cherries, roasted malts, blue cheese fullness and sharpness... Amazing

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ive been interested in this for years. 

Pours a dark cherry with brown tones - like not a stout. Some surface light tan foam. Smells like cherries, wood, some charcoal and cola. Flavor is cherry with some cola flavors, a bit of cocoa, some wood and some raisin. Medium, thin syrup bodied with light on moderate carb. I was interested, then disappointed, now actually quite enjoying this one. I would like it alongside a dark chocolate brownie.

Serving type: bottle

10-27-2012

Bottle, courtesy Brigadier, thanks!! Pour is ruby, off-white head, some retention/good lace. Aroma of cherry, apple, light barrel. Taste is lightly tart, big cherry, light chocolate, apple. Palate is soft, slick, tart finish.
Bottle thanks to somebody, rating from my backlog. The smell is cough syrup, cherry, sweet, and ok. The look is brown in color, clear. The taste is clean, cherry, fruits. Its no stout but not bad.
Bottle. Black pour with tan head. Aroma is cherry and light roast. Flavors are chocolate and cherry, roasted tones. Belgian red + stout?

Bottle shared at Bruces pad, soured via an IP in Merica, 19/09/13.
Dark mahogony brown with a thin tan head.
Nose is cherry forward, light chocolate notes, fruit cake, cocoa poweder.
Taste comprises sweet notes, lgiht cocoa, earthy notes, mineral tones, cherry and chocolate brownies.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, dry finish.
Decent enough if a little over sweet. Wouldnt have this as a fruit beer !!! Stout all over !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: 19th September 2013The Last Tasting at Bruces palatial pad. Ta muchly to Mr Bois. Hazy dark amber beer with a small pale cream coloured head. Light crisp palate, semi dry. Morello cherry, a little tart. Light tangy chocolate. Semi dry finish that is also minerally crisp. Nice Cherry.

Bottle at Bruces, thanks to Colin.. It pours cloudy dark brown with a small beige head. The nose is roasty, toast, sweet cherry, red plum, prune and some tanginess. The taste is red grape, cherry, plum, light tartness, sherbet and sugar and sweetish finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Easy-drinking stuff. Alright.

Bottle shared at Bruces - thanks to Colin. Pours cloudy amber with a light cream head. Lots of tangy cherry in the aroma. Medium sweet flavor, further tangy cherry, mellow pit bitterness, slight funk. Light to medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sweet finish, ripe and tangy cherry, fruity sugars. Quite tasty and very drinkable.
Brownish Red color with some cherry, roast and minor chocolate notes. Good, but its lost some flavor due to age.
Rated in April 2012 (Backlog) - Deep brown with a small off-white head. Aroms is heavy in cherry, mostly cherry cough drops. Taste is heavy in cherry with light roasted malt flavors.

This bottle came home with me from Dark Lord Day 2013. Poured a ruby color looking almost brown in the glass. Small tan head. Medium lacing. Nose of cherry and chocolate Medium to bold in body. Creamy mouth feel. Flavor is very rich and full of cherry and chocolate. Really rich and tasty.

Backlog review. 12oz Bottle. Poured ruby and brown with medium head and lace. Carbonation is on the lighter side of things. Aromas and flavor of dark malt, cherry, oak, chocolate. So much cherry flavor in this one. Excellent brew from NG.

Bottle. Courtesy of tkrjukoff. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy cherry aroma with weak hints of chocolate. Slightly roasted malty sweetish spicy cherry flavor with hints of chocolate. Has a roasted malty sweetish cherry and chocolate finish.

Bottle from Homer321, thanks! Pour is dark brown with reddish hints. Aroma is tons of cherry upfront with some tartness. Flavor is incredible cherry stout. I cant even describe it another way. Just fantastic.

Bottle courtesy of Weihenweizen. Slightly sweet tart cherry and cola aroma - reminds a bit of a cherry coke or Dr. Pepper. Deep chestnut red with a moderate beige head. Sweet tart fresh cherry flavor, nondescript malt and light oak flavor. Medium creamy body, soft carbonation. Absolutely un-stout-like, but absolutely delicious!

Gift from RamyG4.  Awesome aroma of chocolate covered cherries.  The appearance is deep brown, slight translucence, red hue, off-white head.  The flavor is big time cherry, chocolate, caramel, vanilla.  The finish is cherries, light resin.  Medium to medium/thick in body.  Nicely done.

Clear cola coloured body with a brownish tint and a thin, one centimetre tall light brown head. Aroma of pure cherries, fresh, sour, pungent - cherries, from the top of the bottle cap to the whole of the glass - that is an amazing and almost fake smelling beer! Medium to Full-bodied; Strong cherry flavour with a lot of sugars, a good malt backbone and a hint of oak and yeast in the back of the flavour. Aftertaste is long lasting, hitting some sour notes from the cherries, a bit of a effervsence hiding some malt, a lot of oak, bunches of sweetness and more cherries than Ive tasted in most beers! Overall, simply a great beer, but coming from the brewery, youd pretty much expect that, but this is above that, and quite simply one of the best beers Ive had recently. Not as great as Belgian Red, but this was a different beer altogether; Cannot be missed - if you see this, buy it, now. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Discount Liqour in Milwaukee, Wisconsin on 05-September-2012 for US$2.99 sampled at home in Washington on 20-April-2013.

355ml bottle shared by scottatron and ontbeermaker. dark brown, off white head. greatnose of sour cherry mixed with the big malt base of the stout. very fruit forward flavour with the base beer supporting. really good fruit beer.
Holy hell this smells great. dark red color clear. Smells like chocolate covered cherries. Huge cherry taste not much roastyness but adds complexity. I need more new glarus in my life.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2015 12oz bottle, shared by alexsdad06. Clear dark brown color, sort of a light color for a "stout". Bubbly off-white / khaki head. Couple dots of lace. Mostly minimal. Awesome, huge cherry aroma. From the nose and appearance I can already tell that this is definitely more fruit beer than stout. Medium body. Light carbonation. Lightly viscous, but no stickiness in the finish. Lightly tart, light oaky sweet taste. Some very light chocolate in the finish. Tasty treat that Im happy for the chance to try, but it definitely feels past its prime (brad said it was probably a couple years old). The nose held up just fine though, very great aroma. 8/3/6/3/14 Update note, 11/9/15: 12oz bottle, 2007 label, thanks to shigadeyo for sharing. Yeah, pretty much tastes just as I remember. Not changing any scores here, just checking in to say so. Touch of cheese, along with the big cherry. Craig asserts that side by side with aged Belgian Red, most people would be hardly able to tell a difference. I think I agree.

12 oz. bottle, bonusd by ekoerper (thanks Ed), pours a dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma screams truckloads of cherries - nothing artificial about them - smells like pure, fresh cherries, along with a touch of the oak barrels, though not very prominent. There isnt really any notice that this is a stout. Flavour brings out potent cherries upfront, atop a more recognizable (than the nose) stout background. There is a thick malt backing that gives the cherries a big body to sit on top of, making it even more complex. Oak barrels round this off beautifully, but intensifying the complexity. This is truly superb. Cherry (or any fruit) stouts have never succeeded to impress me... until now. Most excellent stuff.
Wow, strong aroma of black and maraschino cherries. Clear maroon, medium cream colored head, good lacing. Sour cherry flavor. Finishes with maple syrup. Mouthfeel is a bit harsh. Delicious.

Bottle at Camp Beer. Pours a cloudy amber with a small white head that quickly diminishes to nothing. The aroma is a strong cherry and oak. Thin mouthfeel with a light malt and strong cherry flavor with nice sweet finish. Easy to drink, a very impressive fruit beer from New Glarus.
Bottle. Pours brown no head. Funky cherry aroma. Taste is like Belgian red with a stout profile

Bottle at home. 2011 Vintage. Pour is black with a deep crimson tint and a frothy off-give head and great lacing. Sweet sour cherries, cough syrup, cranberry juice,  light toffee, and raspberries in the aroma. Awesome, fresh, fruity smell. Taste is pretty tart, sour cherries, light cocoa, a touch of roast, sweet raspberries and cherries, bread, and wood with a lightly smoky/tart finish. Sticky mouthfeel with high carbonation. I would not call this a stout at all. More like a tart fruit beer, with a touch of roast, balancing it out nicely. It doesnt bother me though, this is some pretty tasty stuff; much like all of New Glarus fruit beers.
Shared by some dude at darkness day. Aroma and taste of a cherry sore throat drop. Little too sweet for me.
Dark brown with red edges, aroma like a lumens cough drop. Taste is cherry with a bit of chocolate and only a hint of roast.

I really want to know the story behind why this is called a Cherry Stout. 12 oz. bottle served in a FW mini snifter.

A: Pours a clear dark cherry color with a light tan head. Some light bubbles and and small specs of lace are left on the glass.

S: Smells exactly like cherry coke. I mean exactly like it. The only difference is when I put my nose into the glass the bubbles arent hitting my nose.

T: Dark cherry with a slight sour tang to it. Mild black licorice as well. Almost candied in nature with a high sweetness to it. 

M: Pretty drinkable with a light body and smooth finish.

O: This was an odd beer. While I didnt hate I didnt particular enjoy it. It was a nice beer to try and I would recommend it for cherry candy fanatics.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-27-2012

Pours a rusty deep ruby umber color with a finger of eggshell... aromas are pure fresh juicy black cherry, candy, touches of sour cranberry and oak. Wow... thought from the nose I was in for another messy fruit heavy beer but wait a minute... this is full of smooth silky fruit notes of juicy sour cherries that meld beautifully with a rich slightly creamy dark chocolate that lingers and gets woody and earthy as the sweetness moves away and the stoutish flavors linger. Damn this is soooo good !

Serving: 12 oz. bottle via trade.  It pours a dark brown with a scant tan head.  The nose has a potent dose of cherry candy.  The flavor starts off with that sweet cherry candy note and segues into an odd bitter note. There is some paper, slight wood, and a vegetal malt note.  Not sure where the stout is in this one.  Light to medium body.  I cant figure out what all the hype is about. Overly sweet and a terrible mix of flavors.

Bottle from trade. Aroma and flavors of straight cherries. I have no idea why this is called a stout, but hey, it's awesome. This one has the smoothest palate of any beer I've ever had, and it's not really sweet. The cherry flavor is very similar to the Belgian Red, but it's more subtle and sessionable. Excellent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smells like cherry cola. A little over carbonated. Slightly sour with a little sweetness. OK for a fruit beer but not a stout.

I honestly never wanted to rate any beer as perfect, but I cannot give this any less. Pours a beautiful black with a reddish hue. Nice 2-finger reddish tan head. Smell is absolutely mouth watering! Sweet, fresh picked cherries and chocolate. Taste is perfectly balanced with cherries, sweet cream, sweet tart candy, and a slight milk chocolate and caramel finish. Starts thick and creamy on the palate that thins out slightly upon the swallow. This is absolutely, hands down the best dessert beer ever. Absolutely gold metal, top notch, best of show!

The aroma is overwhelming with fresh cherries and a hint of fresh cut oak.  The flavor is primarily of cherries but quickly dissolves into a nice palate of cherries, barley and an almost caramel tinge from the oak.  Aftertaste is very smooth with a fading reminder of the, ever so delightful tartness of the fresh Wisconsin Montmorency cherries.

Aroma- super ripe cherries, dark chocolate, dark fruits
Appearance- murky brown, looks like sewer water
Taste- super sweet/tart cherry juice, some chocolate, slight roasted notes, more cherry juice on the backend
Palate- normal body and mouthfeel 
Overall- The first half of this beer deserves at least a 4 but the second half became cloyingly sweet and too one-dimensional.  What I would consider novelty.
Bottle at bu11zeye tasting- Nose is cherry syrup, vanilla, roasted malts..Taste is cherry cough drops, cherry medicine, caramel, roasted malts..palate is tart cherry

Pour is a deep-rich cherry-red-brown with a light, mild head.  Aroma is of roasted cherries and earthy notes.  Taste is lightly sweet and with a sour kick.  Lively carbonation.  Overall very good beer.
Another really tasty fruit beer by NG.  Robust chocolate covered cherries.  Deep rich nutty, roasty flavors and a nice sweet/sour cherry backbone.  A little medicinal to me but still great.
Surprisingly doesnt seem like a stout taste but bold and fruity. Wish I could find it more!

Pours unclear dark coffee in color with a smaller beige head. The aroma brings potent sweet and lightly zingy tart cherries very pleasant and prevalent in the nose. The flavor brings the cherry notes as a backbone over the roasted malts, but they blend well nicely. The Wisconsin cherries are sweet with a very smooth tangy tartness that I prefer over the Michigan cherries.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with white head.  Strong medicinal/cough drop cherry aroma with some hints of dark malts underneath. Tart cherry, malty flavor, some hints of oak.  Interesting beer.  It isnt up to par with Belgian Red or Raspberry Tart, but it is a cool fruit beer.

Almost transparent dark brown pour with red highlight, small light tan head.  Aroma reminds me of cherry  coke, with slight cherry tartness.  Flavor is very cherry forward with slight bitterness, and light chocolate and dark roasted malt. Lighter body with heavier carbonation.  Overall I enjoyed this, but I also love cherry coke.  I would probably prefer to drink the cherry coke than trade for this.
bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  amber pour with a cream head.  nose is cherry, cough drops, medicinal.  nice on the palate, cherry, sugar, different than what i was expecting.

Gold medal winning?  Not by me.  This is straight up cherry cola.  Incredibly thin and bubbly.  Big cherry nose and almost cloyingly sweet.  Very thin, like a dark lager.  Tastes like cherry cola with some hoppy bitterness.  Yeah, not good.  Rare failure for New Glarus, especially from the Thumbprint/Unplugged.

Poured from 12 oz bottle.  Pours a murky brown with almost no head while having a fair amount of carbonation.  Aroma is lots of cherry juice and just a hint of chocolate.  Taste follows...very heavy on the cherry flavor and just the slightest amount of chocolate.

Bottle. Pours a a deep red, but very thin  for a stout. Taste has a hint of a lambic more than stout. Good beer though. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to masterchiefMD for sharing this at my most recent tasting.

A: Brown (stout?), ruby-tinged, moderate head and decent lacing

S: Fresh cherries - smells remarkably similar to Wisconsin Belgian Red. This is really different than what I expected.

T: Cherries are the dominant flavor for sure. Sweet and tasty. I have a hard time calling this beer a stout. It drinks more like a dark cherry ale. I was hoping this beer would be slightly thicker and bigger, and not so overrun by fruit...again.

M: Thin, mild carbonation. Decent feel.

D: While it is pleasant, the sweetness becomes cloying rather quickly.

Poured on draft into a snifter. Dark brown and fairly translucent with a thin, beigy head of foam. Not much retention. Aroma is intense ripe cherries and a cola note, not dissimilar to cherry coke. I get a nice chocolate covered cherry note in there as well. Decadent. Taste is a muted dark fruit sweetness that moves to a rich middle and on to a just slightly dry and bitter finish. This beer is right on the verge of being a little tart. This beer is fantastic. Definitely one of the best fruit beers Ive found of yet. Thanks for the bottle, weihenheizen!
Huge cherry flavors. Very light stout. Can tell why this is a fruit beer over a stout. Great non fake cherry flavors
Pours a light black if thats possible. Actually reddish.  Very strong cherry smell and taste.  Tart and not very stout taste. Cant figure this one out. Complex.  Too rich and sweet for this kid

Pours dark brown/black with a medium tan head.  Aroma fleeting roastiness and chocolate beneath nice vinous cherry notes.  Flavor follows suit...its a bit like the wisconsin red with a hint of chocolate...good tart cherry and vinous notes with dark chocolate creeping in late.  Mouthfeel is medium/full and silky with a cherry chocolate finish.  Fabulous.

Very good beer. I would call this a cherry lambic/sour meets chocolate stout. Rich cherry aroma with a clear red-brown color.  Taste starts with a fizzy/carbonated tartness, followed by mellow sweetness, and finishing with a ripe cherry sourness. Very impressive offering once again by New Glarus!
Super dark brown with a small white head. Huge cherry pit and chocolate notes with sweet vinous notes in the finish. The finish is like cherries dipped in chocolate. Awesome.

So I just returned home from a quick Wisconsin beer run. First, I tried the WI Belgian Red which I enjoyed very much, but it was a bit heavy on the fruit for me. So I thought Id take a break and switch it up with a New Glarus Cherry Stout... turns out, they are oddly similar.

Pours like a lighter barleywine. More clarity than youd expect from any stout.

The nose is bossed around by the massive cherries. Faint vinegar, subtle roasted malts... a few suggestions of "stout" but honestly not much.

The production of this beer obviously doesnt differ much from the Belgian Red. The overpowering, tart cherry is supported by some light cocoa and toffee, barely.

As others have suggested, this beer isnt bad at all... just not at all what its advertised as.

12 ounce bottle pours a cocola brown color, aromas of cherries, and thats about it.  Flavors of cherry coke all the way with some vanilla.  Doesnt have many stout quualities, but the beer is pretty good overall.

10 ounce tap pour at some Swiss cabin themed restaurant in New Glarus, WI. Cherry-themed dessert style fruit stouts require an open mind.  It also helps to take it in small doses. Most of us wouldnt eat an entire box of chocolate covered cherries.  Doing that would be ridiculous!  Its equally ridiculous to drink more than 1 glass of unplugged cherry stout.  Its incredibly sweet, rich, and chocolatey smooth.  Have it after a meal and youll feel as if you just drank a milkshake.

Appearance: Pours out a clear, dark brown body with plenty of amber-hued hints at the edges and topped with a slim, off-white head.

Smell: It really just smells more akin to a brown ale given a large, vibrant top note of Ludens Cherry throat drops.

Taste: A roundabout gulp of cherry-flavored cola with extra added toasty malt tastes. Fairly sweet throughout. Lightly tart. Theres a bit of middling woodiness from the oak, but, for the most part, the cherries take center stage. Even farther down into the cherry bin youll find some slight mustiness, but, at best, its reserved. Closes out as sweet and fruity as it kicked off.

Mouthfeel: Medium-plus body. Medium carbonation. Lightly sticky in the mouth.

Overall: Its a very fine beer, dont get me wrong, but not a stout. Instead of "cherry stout" call it "stout cherry", because theres definitely plenty of cherriness within.

The aroma explodes with maraschino cherries and some chocolate on the back end. Its a beautiful looking beer with a thick head and really dark red hue. The taste starts with sweet, sugary, maraschino cherry and ends with a darker chocolate/caramel finish. I like this beer a lot, but its very sweet.

Poured in to my bruery tulip, dark brown with a thin head. Aroma of alcohol and cherries combine to make a cough syrup like aroma. Taste is way better than the nose, lots of cherry juice thins out this stout, the oak is there but the malts arent very present. Not a bad change of pace but not a real stout.

Bottle drank at bu11zeyes 10,000th rating tasting. 

The beer pours a reddish-amber color with a white head. The aroma is full of very sweet cherries. The flavor is very similar. There is a ton of cherry syrup, as well a some lightly roasted malt. Overall, the beer is very sweet. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bottle. It pours a very deep red color with a big khaki head that settles to a nice thin layer. The aroma has huge notes of cherry syrup and dense maltiness. Not a hint of stout here. The flavor is the same. Huge, dense cherry syrup, and beautiful malt character. I dont pick up much oak if any or roasted malts for that matter. It does have a rather hot, spicy finish that is accentuated by a higher than normal carbonation level. The body is full. Mild hints of oak in the very end. Great beer.

Its got a nice pleasant chocolate cherry flavor backed up by a burnt malty backbone, but the palate comes off as unappealing with a syrupy and watery texture. Still worth checking out if youre in the mood for something new.
Sampled at an esbls tasting.  Plenty of cherry red i the dark beer.  The nose is cherry Ludens.  It tastes like that, too.  Some roasted notes but that cherry reigns supreme.  Tasty stuff.

Originally reviewed: 7/8/10. 12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. This pours a dark cola-color - similar to uncreamed-coffee. Theres a thin tan head on top, but lacks depth. Light lace sticks. I smell cherry Jolly Ranchers, cherry juice, etc. The fruit comes full-force in the scent. Some light funkiness to it. Slightly musty. 

The mouth is creamy. Carbonation level is moderate (high for a stout, but decent for a fruit beer). Body is full, but not filling. Wonderful tart cherries all over the flavor. They start out a bit sweet, but have that faint-puckering tartness on the finish. Superb. No roasted aspects noted. I could drink this all day. Wonderful beer. 

Dans done it again. Whether its Raspberry Tart, Belgian Red, Cran-bic, or the Cherry Stout, Dan has perfected the art of the fruit beer. Im blown away.

Bottle, pour is a light black, with a bit of a reddish tint in there, aroma is of cherries and the flavour is a bit roasty up front then finishes with the cherry flavour of the belgian red, overall this one is a enjoyable, fairly sweet but good

Bottle.  Pours a dark, clear reddish-brown with a medium  off-white head.  Aroma of cherries, caramel, roast.  Taste is very sweet, lightly tart.  Dry roasted, woody finish.  Medium bodied, oily texture, moderate carbonation.

From bottle. Pours deep black burgundy with thin khaki head. Very up front cherry with something dark smells. Starts with malty sweet stout flavors and changes to cherry flavors.  Very crisp ending.  Enjoyed this a lot, will buy more.
Wow. Tight this was a stout. First fruit beer I really enjoyed. Great dark roast barley and tart cherry. Wonder if I can get my wife to drink it.

Bottle. Strong cherry aroma, not much malt. Pours very dark with red highlights and a thin tan head. Taste is overwhelmed by cherry and carbonation, not a strong presence of stout. Stays on the palate - pairs very nicely with milk chocolate.

Was expecting a stout, didnt realize it was a fruit beer. It comes across as a milder Wisconsin Belgian red, if I had to choose between the two to drink Id go with this. Sweet, tart, cherry, thin, bubbly. I know a lot of people who like it but Im not a fan of the style.
Bottle from ktown67.  Light brown pour with a tan head.  Aroma is way too cherry and not much stout.  Taste is cherry, roasted malt, alcohol, and a little sour tartness.

(12oz bottle thanks to Ktown67) clearn medium brown with wispy tan bubbles. Nose of fresh cherries, chocolate malt, a bit medicinal but smells great. Taste of cherry, bit medicinal, nice and tart, pretty good.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2012 While called a stout, definitely tastes more of a cherry base with an ale. The malt background is superseded by the cherry flavor, which toes the line quite well between being like cough syrup and not tasting like cherry. While I personally dont love cherry, it was very smooth tasting and the cherry not abrasive or sour. Color is dark red, beautiful with the light coming through it.

Bottle purchased in WI in November 2010 and shared with friends this past weekend. Clear reddish brown pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of cherry and malt with light roast. Cherry flavor with light chocolate and a sweet cherry finish. Tasty, not unlike Belgian Red. If there was ever a lot of stout character to this, its gone now. Still tasty though.
Pours dark brown with huge sweet cherry notes.  Drinks vibrantly with big up front fruit notes that and more complex grains on the back palate.  Long nice cherry notes linger.  Fun stuff!

Bottle from Woodmans in the Falls. Pours a medium brown with reddish tints, quite clear, with some foam. Aroma has cherries. And cherries. Good smell! Taste brings sweet and tart cherry with some subtle milk chocolate and some wood. Finishes somewhat short, but very tart/sweet. I would be curious to retry the cran-bric to see if the lambic-ness is a difference or not. This is not at all stout-y in my opinion, and while very drinkable due to the good cherry flavor, not in belgian reds league.

Superb. Absolutely superb. A cross between Wisconsin Belgian Red and a nice stout, this offers a level of complexity most beers can only dream about.  The spontaneous fermentation stands out and makes this one of the most unique beers out there!

Bottle. Pours clear dark brown with thin, fizzy beige head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is artificial cherries, cereal malt, cardboard, figs, and faint earthy hops. Flavor is sweet malt forward with heavy dark fruit esters; sweet finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

translucent red amber, wispy cream ring, smallest bubbles. Belgian red nose, heavy yogurt with synthetic cherry with medicinal hints. Thin, silky body shows light cherry and chocolate at front, mid with cherry cordial, nearing raspberry tart singularity, some moderate dryness and chocolate coming through in finish with more light cherry, thin body helping fruit survive.

Bottle shared by CaptainCougar.  Pours clear dark brown with a medium, fizzy light tan head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is heavy cherry, light cookie and caramel malt with no hops.  Flavor is heavy cherry, light chocolate malt with a dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation, light warmth.

Very different for a stout, has a very strong sour cherry taste. Maybe a little to powerful of a cherry taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle from Discount Liquors (Milwaukee, WI). An exciting first try here. Pours a rich roasty brownish black hue, good haze but not opaque. A firm ruby brown glow on the edges shines bright. A frothy tannish head atop, healthy layer with ok lacing. Sticks around ok. Aromas are rich cherries, tart but a bigger bite of sweetness. Touches of toast, roast, and mellow cocoa. Some more cherry. Firm. Initial is rich sour and tart cherries up front, lingering on, firm and strong. Middle offers touches of sweetness, biscuits and toffee. Gentle toast and roast, some cocoa and fudge. Cherries take over, Door County would be proud. Backend offers lingering tart and sour cherries, some cocoa, darker malts. The cherries really shine here, remaining sour/tart with minimal malt thickness or attempts to overrun. Very nice, more fruit dominant.

So nice! Pours a deep brown color with a white head. Aroma is cherry and a touch of spiciness. Taste is brilliant with lots of CO2 bubbling everywhere. Bold tart cherry flavor, with some subtle woodiness. If you like their Belgian Red or Raspberry Tart, you must try this beer!!
this is just another in a long line of new glarus beers that hit it out the park

12oz bottle from my reliable Wis. source. A deep brown/red beer with a light brown head. The aroma is sweet with notes of wood, combined with a slight acidity and notes of berries. The flavor is similar to the red but a bit lighter with a hint of sweet with an acidic with strong notes of wood and lesser notes of berries, while leading to a dry end. Overall a unique blend by Dan himself.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/10/2010.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

This pours very light for a stout, almost the same color as a brown ale. Hazelnut or walnut brown with tons of ruby tint. A small off-white head forms upon pouring, with just a touch of lace. Large bubbles cling to the side of the glass.

The aroma of sweet fermented cherries wafts up into my nose. Not really any noticeable malt aroma.

Sweet and sour fermented cherries really control the taste, a bit of dark malt really takes the back seat. Stays sour with some spiced oakiness giving it some additional character at the end.

This has a tart and puckering mouthfeel; medium carbonation and the body comes off as a little bit lighter than medium. Leaves the lips sticky.

The taste was not exactly what I was expecting - a lot heavier on the tart cherries and a lot lighter on the stout - but I enjoyed it. I am actually wondering how they call this a stout. It is more sour than a real stout, but once I got used to that, I would drink this again.

Pours deep red/brown with thin off-white head.  Aroma was my favorite part.  The sour cherries really cam out and it smelled like a cherry pie.  The taste is good with the cherries coming through strong with a little dark chocolate.  Palate is thinner than expected, but overall a very enjoyable beer.

I expected a stout with a little sting of cherry in it. Something dark, mysterious, and big. This was thin and overpowered by the cherries. Its drinkable, but seems more of a sour brown ale than anything else. A rare miss by Dan.

Bottle; Pour is dark brown with garnet highlights in this glass ; a modest fine bubbled off white head is present that doesnt retain well, hazing and ringing the glass. The nose is precisely what youd expect from a barrel aged New Glarus cherry fruit beer. At least, it was for me. Medicinal cherry notes with cherry skins, oaked notes. Probably the highlight of the brew for me - The flavor profile begins with more cherry notes, oak and earth, and pushes towards the malt side of things with chocolate and roast - with a bitterness present, along with general sweetness. Love this one, honestly

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2012 Shared generously by daknole. Ive been wanting this one for a while and it definately wasnt a disappointment. Pour is deep mahogany with a khaki head. Aroma is sweet/tart with notes of chocolate, cherry, oak, and vanilla. Flavor shows the same with a tiny amount of roast to support the berry sweetness as well as some much needed acidity on the backend. Overall body is moderate and is balanced fairly well. This beer reminds me of the belgian red with more depth/balance and a heavier malt profile. Good stuff.

EDIT: After trying a fresh bottle im not as impressed. If the recipe is exactly the same as previous batches, im convinced that this one definately gets better with age. The older bottle I tried had much better balance and the slight medicinal quality found in the newer bottle was completely gone.

I bought a single 12oz bottle from Woodmans in Janesville, WI in early 2012 for $2.69.

Pours a dark brown with a reddish hue to it as well as an off white head. Scent is a blend of barley and sweet cherries. The first part of the taste I noticed is the sweet, tart cherry flavor followed by the bolder, malted stout after taste that had hints of cocoa and coffee. Smooth and sweet to drink. A very complex fruit beer that has much more to offer than just the fruity taste.

Bottle. Pours...clear dark brown with red highlights? Okay, not a stout. Nose is straight-up cherries. No roasted malt character to speak of, but a touch of vanilla from the oak barrels. Seriously, strong cherry aroma, bordering on cough syrup. Taste absolutely nails it, though. Again, more cherries in a big way, hint of oak. Still not a stout, but really succeeds as a stronger, slightly more tart version of NBR.

Cherry Stout pours a very dark brown.  It might look black in that glass but as you pour the brew youll notice its more of a brown color.  Very little head is poured and whatever is poured quickly dies.  No lacing is present. 

Like I said above, this is not really a stout.  Its missing a lot of the stout characteristics you usually see.  No coffee, no roasted malt, etc.  Its just straight on cherry up front.  Its a sweet aroma.  Youll also pick up the barrel characteristics  Oak and vanilla.  Its lovely and something I could just sit there and smell for hours.

Taste is just as good.  With a lot of cherry beers, you might get a medicinal or cough syrup kind of taste.  Not here, its fresh, cherries.  They start out sweet but turn tart.  I also picked up something I didnt pick up in the smell and thats some chocolate.  Chocolate covered cherries anyone? Mixed in there with the oak and vanilla and you have something you just want to drink all night. 

Mouthfeel is a little lighter than you get from a traditional stout.  But its still smooth and goes down way to nice.
Bottle from Keith pours reddish brown with thin tan head.  Aroma of wild cherries.  Flavor of tart cherries and some spices.  Very nice cherry stout.

Poured from a bottle that was probably over a year old. Pours a dark red/black cherry color with off white head. Aroma is fresh cherrys. Taste is oak and cherry with very slight roastyness, little bit of vanilla there to, also slight soda flavor to it. Very lightly carbonated, may be because the age? Leaves a delicious roasty aftertaste, my burps even taste awesome. I would definitely not call this a stout, but it is another amazing new glarus fruit beer. Hope to see this one again in the future.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 Original batch: Pours a dark down to black. The nose and taste are of cherries, coffee, dark malts, cherries, wood, cherries, and cherries. An interesting beer that Im glad I got to try but not a grand slam.- 3.2                                                                      
2012 release: Same notes still apply, however I now really enjoyed this beer. Still a cherry bomb but I found it tasted very well balanced and approachable. My wife who does not drink beer at all drank almost an entire bottle to herself. Very good an very worth trying if you have the means.

(12oz bottle courtesy of Nuplastikk!).  Pours a clear mahogany color with off-white head.  Small, active carbonation bubbles.  Doesnt look like a stout.  Aroma is mostly tart cherries and cherry sucrets.  Taste is sweet cherries, some caramel malts, and a little alcohol.  Medium bodied with a sticky texture.  Smooth.  Nice beer and some obvious similarites to Wisconsin Red.
Bottle, thanx to tkrjukoff. Pours dark brown with a small, light brown head. Aroma of cherry. Sweet/sour to the taste, coffee, cherry. Sour finish.

pretty sure this bottle was 6 years old. .. pours a murky dark tan, light foam .. . lots of cherry in the nose, mild tartness, and a rich molasses, with a berry, light funk, and more cherry .. . a fantastic beer .. He always leaves the TV on the Game Show network. Im not sure why it bothers me, but it does.

From psprings 3/15/11
Cola colored pour no lasting or discernable head actually, still.
The aroma is quite like the Belgian cherrymmmeven down to the cinnamon.
Flavor is the same cinnamon and cherries mixed with roast, chocolate, lactose and coffee-like nuttiness. 
The body is a bit on the thin side and the texture is a little watery. Other than that, this is delicious though not very stout? 7.5/3/7.5/3/15

(Bottle, thanks tkrjukoff!) Pours dark brown with red highlight. Nougat and pink coloured head. The aroma holds ripe cherries up front with undertones of dusty roasted malt, buttery/light spicy oak and chocolate. Light fruit sourish on the nose. The flavour is light sweet, light to medium acidic and tiny bitter. Tones of cherries, light chocolate and buttery/light spicy oak. The mouthfeel is round and light sticky with light carbonation. Tart cherries lingers. A light throat burn from the berries. Light to medium bodied.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours clear cherry mahogany with a small bubbly beige head leaving some lace. Aroma is sweet, cherry and buttery. Flavor is much lika aroma; sourish, a bit pungeant. Missing roasted stout flavor, mostly fruit. Finishes sweet sour cherry.

Bottle shared thx to tkrjukoff cons 2011-07-09 Sätila
AR: nutty, cherries
AP: brownish dark, wee beige head
F: tart,  cherry, nutty, white peppery, heavy bitterness, butter
This brewery rocks ;-)
Bottle, thanks to tkrjukoff. Amber beer with a beige head. Cherry and oak aroma, some chocolate. Cherry flavor, woody, oaky, sourish, some fruit. A bit thin.

Thanks again Dan.
dark reddish brown with ruby highlights.
Thick off white foamy head with a hint of pink.
aroma is strong black cherry dominating, maybe hint of light chocolate under that. Delicious.
Flavour is again, mostly cherry, though not overly syrupy or artificial. Nice medium sweetness with a dry-ish roasted coffeeish malt balancing.

Bottle 12fl.oz.[ Courtesy of Alex420 ]. Clear medium to dark brown red colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, artificial cherries, cherry. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light bitter with a average to long duration, artificial cherries. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110512]

A-pours a dark brown with red edges and a bubbly tight light brown head.

S-tons of cherry juice, very much like belgian red, notes of vanilla underneath with a faint touch of roast in the back.

T-tons of sweet cherries, lightly sour, pound the tongue up front in a good way, light vanilla seems to blend with notes of roasted malts and light touches of dark chocolate behind come in towards the back.  the malt body is very light and could present more strength but does add complexity to the belgian red this seems much like.  those cherries are awesome they have!

M-medium body, creamy feel, a little oily in the back, assertive carbonation lively on the back of the throat, crisp and clean.

D-extremely drinkable beer, much like the belgian red only with notes of roasty rich malt.  the malt could have made more of a presence to make this truly interesting as it seems like a small variation from a great beer.

"It never gets old, drinking those awesome fruit beers from NG. Hot damn! This one was super tastey. Pours a dark muddy brown, with a slight reddish tint to it. Nose is immediately chocolate covered cherries. No suprise there. Mouthfeel was suprisingly not like a stout, maybe more like a porter mouthfeel. Yet creamy and filling. Taste was a masterpiece. Not too sweet, classic tart cherry taste which puts Wisconsin on the map for cherry producers. Initial sweetness, but gives way to a cmore complex and satisfying finish."

bottle thanks to fear025.  brown pour with a thin off white head.  huge deep ripe cherry nose - sweet and a bit tart... with a thin layer of chocolate along with a touch of oak as the beer warms.  big round body filled with cherry juice, light oak, grains, and chocolate.  sweet cherry finish with a bit of roasted malt and more chocolate.  this is definitely a fruit forward beer and has hints of a stout base - especially as the beer warms.

Deep brown pour.  The nose is loaded with bright cherry aroma.  Nice mix of spicy pits as well as sweeter flesh.  There is a faint touch of cocoa to suggest that its a stout, but if I was blindfolded - Im not sure I would have picked it out.  Stlll - despite the sweetness and fruitiness it is a very well-made brew.  Its like an un-tart Belgian Red.

Bottle courtesy of Tyleranderso: Pours a cola brown with a thin tan head. Tart aroma of cherries, followed by a bit of chocolate sweetness. Flavor of the cherries really shine through in this, although it lacks much of a stout character. Sill, a very fine beer in its own right.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2012 Bottle in KC, courtesy of foppa78 (re-rated bottle courtesy of arminjewell). Reddish brown appearance with a brown head. Rich cherry syrup, slightly nutty, light toffee, chocolate aroma. Fairly tart, sweet cherry pie filling, toasty, light chocolate malty, slight toffee flavor with a toasty, moderately tart cherry aftertaste. Update: 2012 version. Quite medicinal, childs cough syrup, cherry aroma with a fair amount of oak. Tingly, super rich, tangy, syrupy cherry flavor that is somewhat medicinal. Way stronger on the negative side than I remember the last version being.

Thanks fear025. This beer wasnt my thing. Pours a light copper brown and sits deep mahogany brown with ruby edges. Nose is very "cherry forward" and dominated by an intense sweet/tart cherry pie character and allows very little of the stout to come through. Flavor is what one would expect from the aroma, very tart/sweet cherry character and very little stout. Low carbonation and medium body with a mild tartness. Definitely a  CHERRY stout.

Pours a dark brown.  Decent head.  Nose is is very much cherry.  Taste was also very cherry and malty.  A little like cherry cola which is good but also a little like cherry cough syrup which I do not find so good.  Farily drinkable.

Pours a dark brown/black with a thin, quickly dissipating off-white head leaving no lacing.

It smells exactly like Wisconsin Belgian Red, no stout scent whatsoever. It is a nice sweet cherry pie scent with a hint of oak.

The taste brings in more stout flavors, this is chocolate covered black cherry beer. This is far from a conventional stout. It has some slight oaky notes as well. Not much tartness, mostly just sugar sweet cherries. It is almost like they just added 10% stout to a bottle of Wisconsin Belgian Red. Interesting.

I like it better than Bells take of the style. It is an immensely unique beer. It looks like a stout 100%, tastes like cherries 95%. Black cherry brew anyone?

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-10-2010 01:36:25

Had this one bottled thanks to Wyl!!  Cloudy, dark brown pour with a rapidly dissipating, fizzy tan head, strong  cherry cola nose, profoundly artificial cherry sweetness completely dominates and overpowers whatever else was meant to be going on here.  Sickly sweet finish.  May not finish this one.

Bottle. Im surprised I havent rated this one sooner as I have had many of these in the past year or so but I guess I just never took notes! As I recall, this is a thin bodied "stout" with a nice cherry flavoring. Poured into a DFH tulip glass a fairly dark, clear reddish brown color with a 2 finger head that slowly settles out. Chery Coke. In fact, more like frozen Cherry Coke is what the aroma reminds me off. Sweet cherries and vanilla in the nose. The taste is not unlike the nose with a heavy dose of sweet cherry flavoring up front with so lingering bitterness in the back end. No real heavy roast notes here by any means. Theres a woodiness quality to it as well. Im glad its labeled as a fruit beer because as a stout I would be pretty disappointed. Some lace left on th glass.
Loved loved this 12 oz bottle from Lushawn.  OMFG good.  Sucrets with sweet malt and chocolate.  Color is very light for a stout.  Beautiful mix of complementary flavors blend perfectly.

12oz bottle, pours a ruby red, some nice tan lacing, sweet cherry aroma, quite nice. This is a lot like the Belgian Red but with some deep malt chocolate, this is very nice. Dangerously drinkable, this is Damn good.

Bottle from Wavers.  Muchas Gracias.  Pours a reddish/dark brown, decent frothy head, and a god damned lovely cherry nose.  Nose mimics Belgian red to a T as far as I can tell.  Flavors very similar as well but with a thicker  malt profile underneath showcasing a very cakey chocolate character.  Its a cherry chocolate cake in a bottle.  Scary drinkable and lovely.

Definite dessert beer here but I went with it for a nice cool evening after dinner drink. Reminds me a bit of a cherry cola. Lots of smooth cherry aroma that comes through pretty big in the flavor with a bit of tartness as well. Rich chocolate malts are faint in the background and round things out in a very interesting way. Cherry is still the dominant flavor but the malt adds a bit of complexity to the drink. A bit of a chalky texture on the finish, cocoa. Very interesting and unique here.

This is uniquely not quite a stout. Id say this is more closely resembling the New Glarus Belgian Red. Lots of tart cherry flavors, but blends well with some darker malt flavors from the stout. I highly recommend this as a dessert beer.

Poured into a pint glass. Thanks to alcstradamus for this.

3.5 A: Clear dark amber color. One finger of somewhat creamy off white head falls quickly, but leaves some lacing.

4.5 S: Much like the Belgian Red, this is all about the cherries. Not really anything else can come out. Though all cherries, it isnt nearly as strong as the Red, but it is still quite nice.

4.0 T: Lots of cherries like the Red, but nowhere near as strong. Unlike the Red, you get to taste some malt. Slight roastiness and a slight burntness are what I pick up the most. Weird mixture of sweet and burntness on finish. I prefer the Red by a lot, but this is pretty tasty as well.

3.5 M: Medium body. Carbonation is a little on the low side. Reasonably creamy.

3.5 D: Another well made fruit beer from NG, but a mere shadow of the Twins.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-03-2010 23:31:58

Bottle: Poured a clear dark red color ale with a huge light brown foamy head with good retention and some lacing  this does not resemble as stout at all. Aroma of cough syrup and sweet cherries is more dominant then I would have expected. Taste is not as overly dominated by the cough syrup notes but cherry taste is quite dominant with light tart aftertaste. Body is about average with good carbonation. I was expecting a stout based on the name alone so I was a bit surprise when I poured this in my glass. Very interesting beer though cherry taste is overwhelming.

Pours an effervescent dark crimson/caramel with 2+ fingers of tan head. Average lacing & head retention

S: Heavy cherry with some woody notes

T: Cherry juice with some booze warmth & not much else up front, maybe a touch of tartness. Winish. Cherry dominates along with a touch of plum hiding on the back of the tongue. Cherry juice finish with some booze sharpness, plus some oaky notes, verging on vanilla

MF: High effervescence. Medium-light body and a watery texture

Pretty drinkable at first, but has some surprisingly rough edges that stand out as you near the end of the bottle. This beer needs food pairings, although I have no suggestion at this time. It was very fresh and different. Almost like a rough lambic.

Serving type: bottle

12 oz. bottle poured to a shaker, displaying a dark brown hue with ruby highlights showing through, a decent amount of lasting, tan head foam, and some clingy ribbons and spots of lacing. The aroma was light roastiness, chocolate, and some cherry tartness. These carried over into the flavor to some degree, but were mainly dominated by the cherry, which also revealed some candied characteristics. There was a light silkiness to the mouthfeel, but the body was a little on the light side to me as a Stout.

Pours a deep dark ruby red that is so dark its almost black with golden ruby edges when held to a light source and a 1.5 finger light beige head. Very good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that leaves streaks of lacing on its way down.

The aroma is bursting with an intense syrupy cherry character. It smells a lot like a ludens cough drop and childrens cold medicine. Whatever oak and malt notes are there are completely overpowering by the overly cloying sweet cherry presence. Im sure they used real cherries but it smells incredibly artificial.

Medium bodied with a cloyingly sweet overpowering cherry flavor. Again it is very syrupy and artificial tasting even if the cherries are real. There are some chocolate/toasted malt notes underneath but this beer is too one dimensional with a boat load of sickening cherry sweetness.
Smells like candy apples and meraschino cherries. Huge fruit nose. Some dark fruit notes. Pours a dark red almost brown in appearance.

Bottle... Poured deep, dark brownish red with little to no pinkish-white head.  The Cherries were so fresh and ripe in this.  No one can produce better fruit beers than these guys.  Cocoa, tart, slight roast, malt sweetness, all enveloped by wonderfull fruit flavors.  A tiny bit medicinal also.

Pour the color of Dr. Pepper with a chocolaty beige head.  Overpowering aroma of cherries.  Overpowering flavor of cherries but possibly some chocolate and vanilla.  Decent amount of carbonation with a clean finish and a medium body.   Honestly, it kinda makes me think of an alcoholic Dr. Pepper overloaded with grenadine.  A very enjoyable take on a "stout".  Thanks bro!

Bottle from a trade with Beerlando. Thx. The pour is dark rubi red with a thin edgy pink head. The aroma bares strongly the notes of artificial or preserved and sweetend cherries - just like the ones we use in our rice pudding at christmas. Besides the cherry there are some faint caramelnotes in the aroma too. The taste is odd and still it strikes me that the cherrys seems artificial and not fresh, sour and tempting. They are all sweet. Besides the markedly cherry there are strong notes of sugar candy and caramels. I dont really think that it has the body to back up the taste. Its quite thin but with a creamy palate that also has a pickin attitude from the alcohol.
Bottle.  Pour is reddish brown with faintly pink head.  Aroma is roasty and cherry with notes of chocolate.  Flavor is true to nose and quite tasty.  very good.

In short: A New Glarus Belgian Red with roasted malts.  Very good.
How: Bottle 12oz.  Age unknown.  Sent to me by brewolf.  Thanks a lot Michael
The look: Clear dark ruby body topped by a persistent small beige head 
In long: Nose of sweet maraschino cherries.  I did not smell a stout here.  It basically smells like a less intense version of New Glarus own Belgian Red.  Taste is burnt toasts, maraschino cherries, wood, generic black cake, light chocolaty notes.  Finish has a surprising bitterness, similar to bitter cherries.  All in all this is more a fruit beer than a stout.  The cherries are really the dominant flavor.  Not quite as good as a Belgian Red but still pretty damn good.  I really like this beer although Im certain that this is just a stout blended with their Belgian Red.  And dont try to prove me wrong.  Im such a smart ass that my butt has a PhD.
Dark brown/red pour.  Sweet red cherries, dark chocolate, and sweet malt.  Mmm excellent cherry flavor.  A good one.
A darker roaster version of Belgium Red.  Simply freaking delicious.  Overall awesome!

Ummm Yes!  There is nothing bad about this beer.  Smells great, looks great and tastes even better.  I know my little stock pile wont last long enough.  I hope they bring this one back sooner than later!

Poured from a 12oz bottle. Wow, I could not have been more disappointed. I know I am in the minority with this one, but this was a rare drain pour from me. Neither me nor the person I shared with could stomach this one at all. I am a big New Glarus fan and this one missed. Nice cherry nose, but the the taste to me was all cherry medicine. I may be being a bit generous with 8 out of 20 overall, but the nose was pretty good and the appearance was average.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a dark brisk red with a thin off-white head. Aromas of dark chcolate andcherries. Flavor is the same, choclate covered cherries... a dark Belgian Red. Really freakingood!!

12 oz. bottle from Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, WI.  Reddish-brown pour with a very thin head.  The aroma is sweet cherries with nothing that gives any indication this is a stout outside of the color.  The flavor is of sweet cherry, as expected from the aroma, with subtleties from the oak aging.  Further tasting does give way to some of the expectations of a stout, mainly chocolate.  This is quite nice.

Traded 12oz bottle. Pours  a nice dark brown with a medium off-white head (I swear it has a hint of red to it also) that settles quickly with just a little lacing. Wow, the aroma is straight cherries: sweet and meaty not sour but almost a touch of cough drop in the finish plus some barrel. Amazing flavor: mix of sweet cherry, sour funkiness plus a strong malt backbone to balance everything out. Extremely well done...again.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2010 Pours brown with a smallish white head. The aroma immediately smacks me in the face, as I am hit by an overwhelming and amazing cherry blast to give with some brown malt. The flavor backs up the check that the aroma wrote, with wonderful cherry flavor that mixes with the malt and some tart and sweet flavors to give one of the most complex flavors I have ever tasted. In many ways, it reminded me of a fantastic Pinot. My only regret is that I have bonitis... wait, I mean that I only had one bottle. Simply amazing beer.

Bottle, thanks to my buddy wavers1.  What a treat.  This was my first from New Glarus and its clear that they have a talent for fruit infused brews.  This one poured a dark brown with a small head that faded in quick fashion to nothing, left some lace.  Aroma was a blast of cherry infused roasted malts.  I think I have to copy the guy who said it smelled like Ludens cough drops, that is dead on, just bizarre.  Flavors were thick with cherry goodness, some malt, roasted, crept in there but cherries dominated, wow.  This is categorized well as the stout factor doesnt play a big role, this is a fruit beer.  The mouthfeel was slick and full, so pleasant.  Finished with a big tartness.  This is one of those brews that really stands out from everything else, I havent come across many of those.  I am amazed.

Had this one thanks to, "hannont". Colour... dark brown with no head. Nose... basically like liquid Ludens Cherry cough drops! I mean that in a good way, as I really like those cough drops!! Palate... oaky, sappy, off-dry (like an extra brut), toffee with cherry hard candies, hints of cherry gummy bears and cherry pie filling. Have I said, "cherry" enough? Am I starting to sound like a song by Warrant? Damn fine cherry stout!

chocolate, brown, black, red, sparkling, tan foam,  light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, fizzy, lively, long finish. 

My first Unplugged this year. This is a fantastic beer. It has an almost champagne like quality. Amazing taste and a great finish. Smells and tastes of chocolate and cherries.

Thanks to Justin for sending this my way.

I poured it into a snifter and it produce a short lived tan head that faded away to a thin lace. The body of the brew was dark brown in color. It has a huge cherry nose on it and the chocolate roast was awesome. It was like a great box of cherry chocolates which have been a favorite of mine since childhood.
The flavor was more of the same sweet and tart cherry and chocolate goodness. A great brew I wish I had more. I hope this makes it to the normal rotation it was to good. I shed a man tear as the last sip passed thru my lips thinking I may never see this brew again

355mL courtesy of CaptainCougar. Pours a clear deep amber with a thin, yet persistent off-white head. Excellent spotty to near sheety lace. Not quite a stout body so I agree with the Fruit Beer category. Aroma at first is cherry Sucrets, coughdrops, Chloroseptic lozenges. As it warms, the powerful black cherries emerge without off character- robust, sweet. Like Dr. Browns Black Cherry Soda. Taste and body is beautiful- soft, tart finish, quick lactic sour that is zippy and quick on the palate. Full, creamy, buttery, meaty body almost like the NG Old English Porter. Really beautiful all around.

Thin brown pour with a whispy tan head.  Aroma is strait Ludens.  I remember growing up always trying to cop some ludens when i was sick.  
More like a brown than a stout still very interesting and unique
bottle, murky black brown pour with dense off white foam, aroma of balsamic, leather and sour cherry, flavor of vinous cherry, pinot, ligth bodied with soft finish

[Bottle] Pours an opaque black color with a thin brown head. Lots of cherry in the nose, along with roasted dark malts. Thes taste is heavily based on natural cherry notes, vanilla, creamy molasses, some wood and toasted nut. It actually tasted like a pretty even blend of their Belgian Red and Road Slush stout. The flavor profile was very defined though, and not muddled like many fruit stouts end up tasting. Solid palate that works well here without covering up the fruit with a bunch of alcohol. Another great creation from New Glarus!

Bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar, thanks!  Very dark brown, small tan head.  Aroma of chocolate covered brandied cherries.  Taste has cherries, vanilla, smooth and silky.  The fruit overwhelms the stout.

12oz bottle from DalzAle.  Pours deep reddish brown with a half finger khaki head.  The nose is mainly cherry sucrets with some roasty malt in the background.  The taste is malt, tart cherry skins, sweet cherry jolly ranchers and some cocoa in the finish.  Medium bodied.  Interesting beer.  Not as good as expected, but still tasty and Im glad to have tried it.  Thanks Greg!

12 oz. bottle. Appearance- Clear deep dark ruby color with minimal head and some lacing. Aroma-Sweet cherry almost like a Cherry Coke. Some of the tartness showing in the aroma. Taste- Lots of cherries with a tart finish. Overall- Even though the cherry character is very prominent the tartness at the end helps balance it out and create a wonderful experience. It doesnt strike me as a stout though.

Bottle thanks to someone but I forgot. Poured a very dark red with opaque edges and an off-white head that laces slightly. Aroma is full of cherries both sweet and tart with a hint of oak. Flavor is similar with sweet cherries becoming more tart and quite smooth. I really didnt pick up much of any stout resemblance but it was an enjoyable as a fruit beer.

Pours a deep dark amber reddish brown. Decent amount of whiteish tan head that dissipates somewhat quickly leaving a small ring of lacing around the glass.

Aroma is cherry cherry cherry.  Flavor is more of the same tasting more like a lambic than a stout really. To be honest Im not really getting any stout notes out off this at all - regardless its a very tasty brew and something Im very glad to have tried.  Another unique beer from New Glarus.  Very light and bubbly mouthfeel, the only thing that keeps it from being more drinkable is the sweetness and intensity of flavors.

Pours a deep but see through copper that turns into a deep brown liquid in the glass with a small off white to tan head. Aroma is cherries, cherry skins, cherry juice, roast, chocolate, barley. The cherry aroma is really fresh and realistic and almost lambic like. Flavor is slightly sour cherry skins, cherry juice blended with chocolate and a touch of roasted barley, the beers fruit characteristics come across cidery and acidic and compliment the chocolate and roast qualities very well. Fantastic, unique, brilliant beer.
A great tasting Cherry Stout. Smooth Cherry taste hard to tell its a beer. New Glarus does an amazing job with their fruit beers

brown, tan head.
aroma, lots of cherries reminiscent of Belgian Red with a mild floral nose, light malts and roast.
flavors, mix of tart cherries with lingering chocolate malts palate, touch of oak that along with the tart leaves a nice mild prickly mouthfeel.
Got the impression this one had a lot of aspects of the Belgian Red with a more stouty approach, dry dusty finish with nice roast and chocolate.

Bottle thanks to billshmeinke. Pours with a clear amber-brown body and a tan head. Aroma of cough syrup, maraschino cherries, amaretto and a slight tanginess. Taste is a bit bitter up front, but very sweet throughout. Some tobacco in the finish. Tastes a lot like Belgian Red. Huge sweet cherries. Not quite cloying though. Was expecting a bit of tartness from the "spontaneous fermentation". Light bubbles. A bit of vanilla in the finish.

I wanted my 100th rating to be a local Wisconsin brew!  Pours a dark cherry brown color with a nice tan/pink head, aroma is full of sour cherries and sweet malt, it has a very tart cherry taste that is very enjoyable with a smooth finish, darn good beer!

Sweet and tart cherries in the aroma, reminescent of cherry red, some subtle milk chocolate. Dark red color, excellent clarity, mocha colored head. Tart (and sweet) cherry, a little more acidity than the belgian red and a bit of vanilla. Finish is tart with a lingering acidity. The wild, barrel and stout characteristics only slighty differentiate this from the BR. Nice beer nevertheless.

Bottle. Pours cherry coke color of red-black with fizzy eggshell head. Aroma of black cherry syrup, roots, hops, caramel, and celery. Strong sour balsamic qualities with black cherry syrup. Sharp bite on the palate. Surprisingly sour. Im not really getting stout qualities. Lots of character with slightly obnoxious tartness from the balsamic.

Bottle.  Pours  brown with a hinr of red with dense frothy sticky off-white head.  Aroma is typical NG barrel, big oak, woody, vanilla, fresh cut oak, big red cherry aroma, fruity candy, gummy bear, not really any stout notes.  Flavor follows, pretty damn good, typical NG barrel flavor, dry wood, vanilla, cherry gummy bear candy, brown ale sweetness, strong flavor that are seemingly well balanced,just very light chocolate, spicy barrel, quick finish.  Well attenuated, sticky soda pop.  Yum yum.

12oz bottle shared with mattyb83 pours brown amber with red hue light with light white head. Aroma screams cherry syrup, oak is noticeable. Taste of cherry balance great with oak and vanilla, oak flavors ride until the end. Very nice and well balanced.

Bottle. Pour is brown with deep red hues in the light, head is a soapy and kahki in color. Aroma is straight cherries and malt. Taste has a strong sour cherry flavor, finishes with faint malt and coco. Palate is medium feel with a chaulky dry finish. This is well balanced and very tasty beer.
bottle pours dark brown with a medium off white head.  Aroma is tart cherry.  Flavor is roasty, lots of malt character balanced with a nice tart cherry with mild sweetness.  Good stuff.

shared by godofthunder.  Rich cherry nose, reminds me of Belgian Red.  Pours brown with rich cherry red hues and a thin white head.  Strong cherry fruits upfront with a hint of tartness with milk chocolate and oaky vanilla following.  Rich and flavorful, very nice dessert beer.

From a bottle.  Pours brown with a hint of red, and a small off-white head.  Aroma is dominated by sweet cherries.  Flavor starts with roasted malts, and quickly turns to sweet cherries and an almost cotton candy like sugary sweetness.  A nice tart cherry finish helps balance this.  Im starting to find many of the New Glarus fruit beers to be very similar.  Its not that they are bad, but they just dont have a distinguishing quality that sets one apart from the others.

12oz Bottle.  A somewhat thinner, dark brown pour, reminiscent of a very light roast coffee.  Aroma notes consisting of super sweet, candy cherry cough drops (Ludens anyone?).  Sweet malty palate, dominated by overwhelming cherries with a slight roasty characteristic. Tartness follows quickly on the finish.  Can easily drink one per sitting, but would not sit down with a four pack.
One sip then fed the drain. This did not work at all. However, i would not hesitate to recommend any other New Glarus brew. This beer reminded me of the cough syrup I got from the doctor as a kid.

This bottle is courtesy of adrian910ss. Hes very generous. Pours a mahogany brown with red tint and a beige head.  Aroma of malt, cherries, and not much else. Doesnt really taste like a stout. Flavour of malt and tart cherries. Basic yet good.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2010 Where we drink NG stout, 
and it taste just like cherry cola, 
c-o-l-a-cola.............

A: The pour is a mildly muddled mahogany color (apologies for the consonance).

S: Pure cherries on the nose. A really nice sweetness and fruit note that is almost reminiscent of the Wisconsin Belgian Red.

T: The cherries come through strongest off the bat and are nice and sweet, but not artificial tasting at all. As the beer warms and subsequent sips are taken, a nice chocolate flavor comes out. This one has an almost tootsie roll taste to it.

M: The body is medium with a nice moderate carbonation to it.

D: One of the best of the Unplugged beers to this point. I really loved the great cherry flavor and the stout component underneath.

The Dan Journal #371.  Tasted 7/12/10.  12oz bottle.  Filtered with a deep dark ruby hue.  Layered head.  Aromas of cherry candy first, followed by a deep, rich chocolate note.  Mild cocoa dust.  Very full bodied with a huge dominance by the cherries.  The stout aspect definitely takes a back seat.  Sweet candy cherry flavors instead of the tart.  Overwhelms, but melds nicely with the rich chocolate malt flavors.  Mildly tart and roasty.  Great but rather sweet!  But thats ok with me!

12oz bottle pours a deep, mahogany brown with a thin, white head.  Nose is malty, cherries, dark bread.  Flavor is cherry juice, Christmas fruit cake, apples, LOTS of juice.  Too much juice in the flavor.  Finish is medium bodied.

This poured a very dark brown color with a smaller beige head. Aroma was lighter chocolate and coffe notes lightly drizzled over loads of tart cherries. Flavor was much the same as the aroma, its basically tasted like the belgian red mixed in the blender with a chocolate bar. Great stuff.

Slight red tinted opaque dark brown pour with a thin light tan head.  Strong cherry aroma, nice and fresh.  Slight sourness and a bit of grape.  Flavor almost like soy sauce.  Slightly sweet with lots of slightly tart cherries and some coffee.
Pours dark brown. Huge cherry aroma, flavor is chocolate covered cherries.  Lots of roasty malt to provide some balance to the overwhelming cherry, quite sweet but not too sweet.  Tasty.

Awesome fruit beer.  Character of stout is muted due to extraordinary cherry and wild yeast flavors.  More lactic acid style fermentation than barnyard, if you will.  Strong sour cherry flavors, not terribly unlike the caramelized sugar booger you might pull off the edge of a cherry pie.  My wife said it tasted like cough syrup.  I disagree, better medicine than that for sure.  Delicious!
6/26/10.  Sampled at the Tally Tasting 2010 courtesy markwise.  Smells like an oaked cherry cough drop.  The flavor is sweet cherry with a hint of chocolate. Really digging the flavor.

A big hearty thanks to my cousin for a bottle of this Wisconsin nectar!  He said I would love this, and he was right on.  My 1000th rating is coming up soon, and I wish I had saved it for that.  Interesting label notes thank the drinker for supporting the brewing arts that went into this handcrafted, limited release.  "Drink indigenous" says the secret message on the cap.  The aroma is floral, sour-sweet cherry juice.  The flavor is even better - lots of fresh from the orchard cherry juice, along with smoky malt (8 types), brown sugar, lime, and a light touch of drying hops.  Wow.  Wow - amazing beer!  One of the best, i.m.o.  It is more like a strong American fruit ale than a stout.  Fresh, earthy, and full of natural flavor.  Unplugged Cherry Stout is a great brew, maybe even the best I have had from this superb brewery.  Hats off to Daniel Carey and the rest of New Glarus for this and their other "unplugged" brews.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2012 12 ounce bottle courtesy of MrPickles. Thanks! Opened 6/7/10. Pours a orange-brown color with a thin head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of candied cherries, a milky note and some brown malts. The taste is dominated by cherries, both fresh and candied, with a lightly roasty note and some nutty notes. Medium bodied and smooth. Cherry stouts are a style that do not agree with me at all, and this like all the others has a medicinal quality. That said, this is very good and if I liked the combination of roasted malts and cherries, I would love this one. 7/3/8/4/14Had a bottle at CaptainCougars, shared by Captain Cougar. Pours a hazy dark brown color with a thin tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of tart cherries, molasses, roasted malts and honey. The taste is tart cherries, faint roasted malts, honey. Medium bodied. Very, very nice. 9/3/8/4/18

Purchased at the brewery.  Pours reddish brown with minimal white head.  Aroma of Cherries.  Sweet and medium tartness.  Hints of malt and light coffee.  Medium body.  A fantastic brew!  Its hard to believe it is 6.5% abv.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a refrigerated shaker.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights.  Has an off-white head with medium carbonation and nice lacing.  Taste is cherry and light roasted malt.  Not like any stout I have had, but good beer.  Hard  to get, so if you are in Wisconsin, try it.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2012 [Bottle] Pours brown with a small beige head. Aroma is huge on cherry and black currants, with notes of watermelon jolly rancher. The taste is cherry, then some sort of roasted malt, followed by tart cherry skins, fruit punch, cocoa and subtle notes of coffee. Unusual, but very enjoyable. Medium mouthfeel, smooth, long dry finish. Wow, another very unique and enjoyable beer from New Glarus. I could drink this one all day long. Old rating: 7/3/9/4/17=4.0New rating: A blast of cherry with some malt and light cinnamon. Taste is so unique and enjoyable. Tart cherry skins blend with cinnamon, barley, and some oak. Wow. So often I am disappointed by beers these days, but Dan Carey rarely misses. This is even better than I remember, and just an amazing dessert beer.  I can see how some people would not care for this beer, but I love it.

12oz bottle. Pours dark brown with hints of transparency, not as dark as your typical stout. Aroma is of dark fruits, sweet cherries and light caramel malt. Mouthfeel is thin with moderate carbonation. Taste of a chocolate covered cherry extract, much like other New Glarus beers that use fruit this beer is WAY too sweet for my liking.

Tallahassee Tasting at Proof/Liquor Loft - 12 oz bottle. Dark black pour. Nice aroma of fresh cherries. Flavor is full of fresh cherries with just the right amount of sourness. Turns just a bit chemically in the finish. Decently thick mouthfeel.

Cherries? Great fruit. Stout? Great beer. Cherry Stout? Unfortunate combination. I dont understand it, but whenever two of my favorite things are combined, I always seem to be disappointed. The only time two Rights made a Right was Willie and Waylon (and Bob and the Band, I suppose).
Bottle. Ruby red pour with a small cream head. Aroma is candied cherries. Taste is cherry syrup. Yummy stuff.

Aroma:Extremely sweet maraschino cherry.

Appearance:A pretty dark red. Medium head retention. Nice lacing.

Taste:First, cherry hits you, as if you were drinking maraschino cherry juice and sour cherries. Next, the medium flavor turns sour, funky and wild. The aftertaste leaves you with mild cherries.

Palate:Medium body, nice carbonated feel. Creamy aftertaste.

Overall:This is a complex brew, with every sip, I get something different out of it. Its dark, like a stout, but the dark malt cant fight through the cherry flavor.

Bottle courtesy of CanIHave4Beers.  Pours dark brown with slightly reddish tint and small bubbly beige head.  Nose of (surprise) cherries, mostly dark cherries with woody notes and very mild roasty stout notes.  This one is all about the cherries.  Tastes like sweet cherries with mildly sour oak kick and stout-like notes that make me think of a roasty brown sugar/cinnamon thing, though that doesnt quite capture it.  Palate is thin.  Love this beer.

Pours deep brown with a thin off white head.  Aroma is pure cherry, but not artificial at all.  A little sour with some chocolate notes. Flavor is very fruit forward, but not cloying. Really good balance.  Some malt character, but the cherries are the star.  Good beer.

Bottle acquired via trade with fear025...thanks Jay!!!  Another incredible beer by an incredible brewery.  Maraschino, Bing, and Rainier cherry aroma burst out of the glass during the pour.  The nose on this one is definitely more Belgian Red than Road Slush stout.  Very little cocoa, coffee, caramel, or oak make their way into the aroma but it smells so damn good that I have a hard time not giving it a high score!  Not a dark or intimidating stout in any way.  Instead, this one is more ruby red/crimson in color and produced a small eggshell head.  Flavor shows more stout notes of toffee, roasted malt, and even a little chocolate.  Medium mouthfeel.  Man I wish this stuff was available locally!

12 oz. bottle; thanks Tom!!  Clear dark brown with trace off-white head; big sweet aromas of mildly tart cherries and chocolate;  texture is quite thin and very fruity overall; almost no stout IMO but more of a thin chocolate and super cherry desert beer; lovely rich cherry and mild roast mix; delicious

Thanks to Iowaherkeye for sending these my way. Pours a blackish with red highlights. Gorgeous beer. Nose is significant cherry, with roasty chocolate and nutty notes. Sort of cherry colaish oddly enough. In a good way. Juicy cherry up front with subtle roast and chocolate notes. This is a lighter beer I assume because the body is less than most imperials. Super smooth and very easy to drink. Again I am reminded of a fantastic cherry cola made with real cherries. Chocolatey and lightly roasty on the finish but the cherry is what lingers along with nice woody vanilla notes. I dig this and I could drink this stuff all day long. Terrific.

Black body with a hint of red in the light.  Aroma is a sweet cherries with note of sour, some chocolate undercurrents and some acidity.  Flavor comes through with a well-rounded notes of cherry that are wonderfully balanced by the chocolate roasted notes of the malt.  Finishes with a note of sour tannins followed by a lingering cherry sweetness.  A lovely beer.

Blackish red pour with a thin off white head. Tart cherry and barrel aroma. Tangy slightly tart cherry taste, hints of roasted grain and barrel in the taste. Funky mix of stout and fruit, outstanding.

Bottle.  Pours a clear ruby hued dark brown with a medium large soft beige head, very creamy.  Initially smells a bit like Ludens cough drops.  Huge cherry aroma.  Smelling this blind, Id never peg it as something dark, just piles of cherry.  Really big sweet cherry at the start, a bit like pie, vague hints of roast and toffee in there.  Very tasty.  Finishes with a bit more touches of roast, but still pretty much hidden by the cherry.  Again, blind I doubt Id even pick up some of the stout notes, apart from it having a bit more body than Id expect from a fruit beer.  Another tasty fruit beer from New Glarus, but I guess that really shouldnt surprise me.
Aroma is a bit off-putting.  It reminds me, uncannily, of Ludens Cherry cough drops.  Flavor is a quite pronounced sweet-tart cherry that dominates.

Bottle from a trade with MIBRomeo. Pours dark brown color with tan head. Aromas of tart cherries, chocolate and oak. Sour cherry flavor with milk chocolate, roasted malts  and oak. Wow, this beer is really different. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Good stuff. Thanks Chuck.

12 oz bottle...  this stuff really suprised me.  It tastes like the belgian red  aged in chocolate.  Poured black, with strong cherry scents.  light head and lacing.  
strong cherry tastes.  Overall very good.
